review_title: Some services are great to work in, others not so much
job_title: Support Worker in London, England
pros: Good benefits, generous holiday, yearly bonuses, opportunity for progression if you have the right manager, some services can offer flexibility if they are fully staffed. Lots of training if you are working in a service that can release you to attend it (i.e. not really short staffed). Some jobs can be done from home. 45p mile. Provided with surface pro and mobile phone. Good employee assistance programme and discounts package.
cons: Lack of job security, very low pay, some services refuse to offer any flexibility and very understaffed, so expect to do the work of 5 people for the price of one. Company prefers to pay agency staff than increase the salary for frontline workers. Permanent staff will be refused holiday requests on bank holidays due to agency costs of cover, yet services are left with dangerous staffing levels a lot. Customers pay a support charge as part of their rent, and do not receive the level of support they pay for, due to being so understaffed. IT department is rubbish and take months to give you access to systems, and then you will be told off for not having systems up to date, even though you are understaffed and have not had access to them. No one will show you how to use systems. All information has to be recorded on lots of different systems, so there is a lot of duplication of paperwork. Some of the managers in the service are really good, it all depends which service you work in what your experience of the organisation will be. There is a lot of opportunity to move around within the company.

review_title: Company that cares but kinda doesn't...
job_title: Assistant Development Manager in Leeds, England
pros: Home Group have a good work ethic, opting for flexible working allows employees to plan their own hours in any manner that meets their lifestyle and home obligations. They have a decent reward scene that provides some good discounts on shopping, gyms, bikes etc. The ethos of the business is good, as it is a charitable organisation, you can really take pride in your work when your work is actually delivering affordable housing - not so much when delivering the ORS tenure homes.
cons: Home Group talks a good talk, promises of a human focused business, putting customers and employees first, but the charm wears off quick. If you are based outside of the head office in Newcastle you won't see the Exec team, even your director, nor will you get opportunity to speak with them virtually or voice concerns. There is currently no way to plan your career progression within the Development New Business team even though they have this 'grow our own' movement to keep people within the organisation, there isn't any incentive to. Staff retention is low due to lower than average wages and lack of communication flow from the top of the pyramid to the bottom. All the information flows through a Facebook mirror called Workplace, where important information is posted but is quickly drown out by dog pics and charity events - not that these are bad but encouraging scrolling through social media isn't healthy or a good way to engage and inform everyone in the organisation. Annually there is a feedback form that allows you to voice concerns but none of the questions allow you to voice concerns over the exec team or the direction of the business, only about you head of and managers. This usually leads to the results being skewed as the head ofs and managers are usually human focused and get good results, but if the criteria of the feedback was expanded, Home Group would lose their place in Stonewall's top big business category.

From day 1 you feel that you are an individual who can really make a difference to peoples lives including those who may be vulnerable in some way.  

There's also real opportunities for progression.  I joined as an advisor on the phones and then progressed to Team Leader.  I have now progressed to a more senior role and love it.   It can be challenging but you get out what you put in.  

Work life balance is really promoted.  When the working day ends you can switch off.  You also get great holiday benefits.  You start with 25 days plus bank holidays.  This rises by a day for every year up to 30 days.  You can also buy a week.
cons: You can sometimes deal with some difficult customer situations but you will be supported.

review_title: A solid, care orientated company with a great mission.
job_title: Project Based Support Worker Level II in Norwich, England
pros:
In short;

CARING - COMMERCIAL - ENERGISED - 

"To build homes, independance and aspirations".
Home Group has wonderful missions from proving affordable, high quality homes for first time buyers or rehabilitating and supporting vulnerable persons with drug and alcohol issues back into society.
 All managers I have met are extremely kind, caring and fair people. I have had no  negative experiences with high, mid-tier or lower management. As an example, the company is currently undergoing a restructure. These times are worriful, stressful and unpeasant for many people at risk of losing their jobs. Home Group, like all others lack the ability to make this process painless, however, the communication from higher management all the way down to front line support has been stalwart. Nobody feels in the dark and everyone feels at ease to make their own decisions regarding their future, or not, at this company.
 The hiring process (interview), unfortunately, is point-based. Whilst I fundamentally disagree with this method, the teams I have worked for and with have hired some truly wonderful and inspirational people. If you have a story to tell and a drive to help and inspire through personal care, mental health work, housing experience or a desire to aid the homeless there will be a place for you at Home Group.
cons:
Whilst I have my reservations about my current position (mostly around shift-work and stressful environment on a local level) the company as a whole has a solid outlook. 
 You will find 'Cons' to be a little short in Home Group if you are a person with care to give and a story to tell.

job_title: Support Worker Bank in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Very flexible-you can choose what shifts you pick up and when you work, making it great for students or those with other jobs. As a full time student, being able to choose my hours is perfect for me to fit around my studies.

Pay is above minimum wage

Most locations are fairly central and the majority are near to a metro station which is great for those who rely on public transport.
cons:
Little to no training-you are required to complete e-learning modules (which have very little relation to actually doing the job) but get no physical in-person training. My very first shift I got sent to another premises 10 miles away to cover. When i arrived I was the only member of staff there-I had no idea where anything was, what my job even really entailed and no idea what was required of me, and I was given no number to contact for help. The clients had to tell me what I needed to do and where the office was, which was extremely embarrassing and unprofessional. 

Very few shifts-there are very few shifts available for bank staff to pick up, and because of this its rare you actually get a shift. I apply for almost every one and if I get one every fortnight I'm lucky. 

Poor management-you get very little support, and management are quick to blame if something goes wrong, despite no support or training. 

The vast majority of shifts are cancelled at short notice-if you manage to get accepted for a shift, the majority of the time it is cancelled at short notice, usually a few hours before (or once five minutes before when I had already arrived, though often they don't even notify you, so you'll turn up to work and get sent away, with no reimbursement for travel expenses). 

Not able to support yourself on the wage-unless you're really lucky and get loads of shifts, its impossible to live off the wages. You are told at the interview that you can work as many hours as you want and its completely possible to work full time hours, but its pretty much impossible.

Honestly, its a terrible company to work bank for (not sure about full time, though people who work full time seem to have a better experience). Management seem to have little respect for bank workers and its overall a horrible, stressful experience.
